option_1_explanation: Correct! The passage explicitly states 'If you stay on the pool floor for a few seconds, you will feel pressure in your ears.' This is a direct example from the text showing how water pressure affects the body even at shallow depths.

option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The passage does not mention breathing problems when staying at the bottom of a pool. The focus is on pressure you can feel in your ears. Review the example in paragraph 1 more carefully.

No land animals can survive the water pressure of the deep ocean. Most fish cannot either. However, there is lots of life down there! How do we know this? Scientists have created special underwater vehicles called submersibles that can go very deep. A submersible is different from a regular submarine. Some submersibles can carry one or two people. Others are controlled from the surface using remote controls.

---

With lights and cameras, a submersible can explore the deepest parts of the ocean. Scientists made the first submersible about 50 years ago. They have been discovering amazing fish ever since! Fish that live deep in the ocean are unlike any other creatures. They have very thick bodies to handle all that water pressure.
No sunlight reaches the bottom of the ocean, so it is completely dark down there. Many deep-sea fish actually glow! Lantern fish are the most common deep-sea fish. There are billions of them swimming in the deep ocean. The anglerfish is one of the strangest creatures on Earth. It has a huge mouth and scary teeth. It also has something like a built-in flashlight on its head to talk to other fish.

---

Humans have only explored a tiny part of the deep seas. There are still many creatures waiting to be discovered. If you want to discover new ocean animals, you might want to become a marine biologist. A marine biologist is a scientist who studies ocean life and explores the mysteries of the deep sea.

option_1: 'The deepest part of the ocean is more than six miles down!'
option_2: 'Some parts are only a few yards deep.'
option_3: 'Divers use scuba gear to breathe underwater.'
option_4: 'You can feel this pressure when you swim to the bottom of a pool.'

option_2_explanation: Correct! This sentence comes right after the question 'How deep are oceans? It depends on where you are in the world,' and shows that some parts are shallow while others are very deep. The word 'some' indicates variation, proving that different locations have different depths.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. This detail is about equipment divers use, not about how ocean depth changes in different places. Reread paragraph 2 where depth is discussed.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. This example is about feeling pressure in a pool, not about how ocean depths differ by location. Focus on details that compare different ocean areas.

option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The passage does not suggest scientists must study shallow-water fish before deep-sea fish. The key barrier is reaching the deep ocean, not the order of study.

question: Based on the passage, what would most likely happen if submersibles did not have remote control capability?
option_1: Scientists would discover fewer deep-sea creatures than they do now.

This means remote control allows for more exploration vehicles. Without this option, fewer submersibles could operate (limited by human capacity), resulting in fewer discoveries. option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Fish survival does not depend on submersible technology. Deep-sea fish survived long before submersibles existed. Consider what submersibles are used for according to the passage.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Marine biologists could still use submersibles that carry people, so they would not need to change careers. The question asks about the impact of losing one capability, not all exploration methods.

question: In section 2, the word crushed means
option_1: dropped
option_2: moved
option_3: lifted
option_4: squeezed
option_1_explanation: You may have chosen “dropped” because the text says it would feel like 3,300 elephants dropped on you, but notice “the more water pressure you feel… because of the weight of all the water around you,” which shows the force is all around you. That means “squeezed” fits best, since pressure pushes and crushes from every side. Next time, reread the sentences around an example and pick the word that matches the main idea, not just the picture in one line.
option_2_explanation: You may have thought pressure makes things move, but the text says “A person would be crushed to the size of an ant,” which shows pressure presses in on you, not moves you. That’s why squeezed is correct and moved is not. Tip: reread the sentence and try swapping each choice into it—clue words like crushed and strong pressure point to squeezed.
option_3_explanation: You may have thought pressure makes you feel lifted, but the passage says you “feel pressure in your ears” and that a person at the deepest part would be “crushed to the size of an ant,” which means the water is pushing in on you. So the correct answer is squeezed because deep water pressure presses your body from all sides. Next time, look for clue words like pressure and crushed to be sure your answer matches what the text describes.
option_4_explanation: Great job! You used context clues to figure out the word meaning by matching “squeezed” with what happens under strong water pressure. The text says, “The water pressure there is incredibly strong… A person would be crushed to the size of an ant or smaller,” which shows “crushed” means squeezed. Next time, read the sentences around a tricky word and look for examples or comparisons that explain it.

Deep-Sea Fish
    
    
        Oceans are very deep bodies of water. People cannot go very deep into the ocean, even with special equipment. Divers use scuba gear to breathe underwater. This includes a tank of oxygen and other tools. But there is still a limit to how deep anyone can go.
The deeper you go, the more water pressure you feel. This happens because of the weight of all the water around you. You can feel this pressure when you swim to the bottom of a pool. If you stay on the pool floor for a few seconds, you will feel pressure in your ears. In the ocean, this pressure gets much stronger as you go deeper.

---

How deep are oceans? It depends on where you are in the world. Some parts are only a few yards deep. Other parts can be around 10,000 feet deep. The deepest part of the ocean is more than six miles down! The water pressure there is incredibly strong. It would feel like 3,300 elephants dropped on you at the same time. A person would be crushed to the size of an ant or smaller.
No land animals can survive the water pressure of the deep ocean. Most fish cannot either. However, there is lots of life down there! How do we know this? Scientists have created special underwater vehicles called submersibles that can go very deep. A submersible is different from a regular submarine. Some submersibles can carry one or two people. Others are controlled from the surface using remote controls.

---

With lights and cameras, a submersible can explore the deepest parts of the ocean. Scientists made the first submersible about 50 years ago. They have been discovering amazing fish ever since! Fish that live deep in the ocean are unlike any other creatures. They have very thick bodies to handle all that water pressure.
No sunlight reaches the bottom of the ocean, so it is completely dark down there. Many deep-sea fish actually glow! Lantern fish are the most common deep-sea fish. There are billions of them swimming in the deep ocean. The anglerfish is one of the strangest creatures on Earth. It has a huge mouth and scary teeth. It also has something like a built-in flashlight on its head to talk to other fish.

---

Humans have only explored a tiny part of the deep seas. There are still many creatures waiting to be discovered. If you want to discover new ocean animals, you might want to become a marine biologist. A marine biologist is a scientist who studies ocean life and explores the mysteries of the deep sea.

option_1: The way lantern fish produce light
option_2: The cameras used on submersibles
option_3: The special feature on an anglerfish's head
option_4: The tool divers use to see underwater
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. While lantern fish are mentioned, the 'built-in flashlight' phrase specifically describes a different fish. Read carefully to see which fish has this feature on its head.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. Submersible cameras are mentioned earlier, but this phrase describes a feature of a specific deep-sea fish, not equipment. Look at what animal is being discussed in this sentence.
option_3_explanation: Correct! The passage states the anglerfish 'has something like a built-in flashlight on its head to talk to other fish.' Using context clues, you can determine this phrase describes the light-producing organ on the anglerfish that helps it communicate.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Diver equipment is discussed in paragraph 1, but this phrase appears in paragraph 3 about deep-sea fish characteristics. The phrase describes a body part of a fish, not human equipment.

option_4_explanation: Incorrect. While depth can be measured in feet, limit does not mean a distance measurement. It refers to a maximum point or boundary. Consider what 'a limit to how deep' means in context.

question: The word incredibly in paragraph 2 most nearly means
option_1: slightly
option_2: extremely
option_3: carefully
option_4: recently
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. Incredibly does not mean slightly. The passage describes the deepest ocean pressure as being like 3,300 elephants - this is not a slight or small amount. Look for a word that matches this extreme description.
option_2_explanation: Correct! The passage says 'The water pressure there is incredibly strong' when describing the deepest part of the ocean. The context of extreme depth and the elephant comparison shows incredibly means extremely or to a great degree.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Carefully describes how something is done with caution, not the intensity or degree of strength. The word incredibly is describing how strong the pressure is, not how it acts.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Recently refers to time, but incredibly describes the degree or intensity of the pressure's strength. Consider what incredibly tells you about how strong the pressure is.

question: The author most likely wrote this passage to
option_1: show how submersibles are better than submarines for ocean exploration.
option_2: explain why ocean exploration is dangerous.
option_3: describe the challenges and discoveries of deep-sea exploration.
option_4: tell about different types of ocean fish.
option_1_explanation: You may have focused on one small detail about submersibles, thinking the passage was comparing them to submarines. But the text only says “A submersible is different from a regular submarine,” and mostly explains the hard parts of going deep (strong pressure, no sunlight) and the discoveries there (glowing fish like lantern fish and anglerfish). So the main idea is the challenges and discoveries of deep-sea exploration. Next time, check that your answer matches what the whole passage is about, not just one sentence.
option_2_explanation: You may have focused only on the danger, but the text also shows how submersibles use lights and cameras and “have been discovering amazing fish” like lantern fish and anglerfish—so it’s about discoveries as well as problems. The correct answer is describe the challenges (strong pressure, darkness) and the discoveries because that fits the whole passage. Next time, check that your answer covers what the whole passage is about, not just one detail.
option_3_explanation: You successfully found the main idea by noticing the text first explains the challenge of going deep (strong water pressure and limits on divers) and then describes what scientists discover with submersibles. The text supports this with “The deeper you go, the more water pressure you feel” and “With lights and cameras, a submersible can explore… They have been discovering amazing fish ever since… Many deep-sea fish actually glow.” Remember to ask, “What is this mostly about?” and use the title and repeated details to connect the challenge with what scientists found.
option_4_explanation: You may have chosen the fish answer because the passage names lantern fish and anglerfish, but notice how most of the text explains the problems of going deep (strong water pressure, no sunlight) and how submersibles help scientists explore and discover new creatures. That shows the main purpose is to describe the challenges and discoveries of deep-sea exploration, not to list fish types. Next time, make sure your answer matches the whole passage by rereading the first and last paragraphs to find the main idea.

question: What is the main idea of this passage?
option_1: Scuba divers can explore shallow parts of the ocean safely.
option_2: Deep-sea fish have adapted to survive in extreme conditions.
option_3: Scientists use submersibles to study the deep ocean and its creatures.
option_4: Marine biologists work to discover new types of ocean animals.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. While scuba diving is mentioned briefly in paragraph 1, it is not the main focus. The passage emphasizes what happens in the deep ocean where divers cannot go. Consider what topic appears throughout the entire passage.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. Fish adaptations are discussed in paragraph 3, but this is only one part of the passage. The main idea should cover the broader topic that connects all sections. Look for what enables scientists to learn about these fish.
option_3_explanation: Correct! This captures the central focus that connects all parts: the passage explains the challenges of deep-sea exploration (paragraphs 1-2), introduces submersibles as the solution (paragraph 2), describes what scientists have discovered using them (paragraph 3), and concludes with future possibilities (paragraph 4). The relationship between submersibles and scientific discovery unifies the entire text.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Marine biologists are mentioned only at the end as a career possibility. This detail supports the main idea but is not the main idea itself. Look for the topic that dominates most of the passage.

question: The author organizes the passage to show that
option_1: different types of fish live at different ocean depths.
option_2: marine biologists are more important than other scientists.
option_3: understanding ocean challenges led to technology that enabled discoveries.
option_4: submersibles are safer than submarines for ocean exploration.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. While the passage mentions different fish, it does not organize information around fish at different depths. The structure focuses on problems, solutions, and results. Consider how the paragraphs build on each other.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. The passage does not compare marine biologists to other scientists or claim they are more important. Marine biologists are mentioned only briefly at the end. Look at the overall flow of ideas.
option_3_explanation: Correct! The passage is structured logically: it first establishes the problems of deep-sea exploration (pressure, depth, darkness), then introduces the solution (submersibles), then describes what this technology has enabled scientists to discover (amazing fish), and finally looks to future discoveries. This organization shows cause and effect across the entire passage.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. While the passage distinguishes submersibles from submarines, safety comparison is not the organizing principle. One sentence mentions the difference, but this is not how the whole passage is structured.

passage_text:
Tree Frogs
    
    
        Amphibians are special animals that live in two places. They spend part of their lives in water and part on land. When they are babies, they have gills like fish. This helps them breathe underwater. Later, they grow lungs so they can breathe air on land. Tree frogs are one kind of amphibian. They are different because they spend most of their time up in trees.
The American green tree frog lives in the southeastern United States. These frogs are very small. A typical tree frog is only about two inches long. But they can make a lot of noise when many of them get together. If you live in the southern United States near water and trees, you might hear their gentle chirps on summer nights.

---

American tree frogs can be lime green or yellow in color. Their most special feature is their long toes. Each toe has a suction cup at the end. These suction cups help tree frogs stick to anything they want to climb. They can even stick to windows! Tree frogs like to stay up in trees, so you will probably hear them before you see them. They only come down to lay their eggs. They are most likely to come to the ground after heavy rain, when everything is wet.
If you do see a tree frog, don't be scared! They are friendly animals. They are easy to catch too. If you catch one, it might sit on your hand or crawl on your back. You will probably only find them at night because they are nocturnal. This means they sleep during the day and are awake at night. They eat small bugs like crickets and moths.

---

Like other amphibians, American green tree frogs lay their eggs in or near water. Most of them like to put their eggs very close to water, but not right in it. Their favorite spot is on a tree branch that has fallen into a pond. Tree frogs have been around for a very long time. They lived on Earth even before dinosaurs! You can find different types of tree frogs in North America, South America, Europe, and Southeast Asia.
Most tree frogs like a warm, wet climate. If you live where tree frogs are found, you are lucky! In the summer, you can fall asleep listening to the sounds of many tree frogs singing together. It sounds like a beautiful orchestra of nature.
question: Why do American green tree frogs have suction cups on their toes?
option_1: to help them catch small bugs
option_2: to help them stick to things they climb
option_3: to help them make loud noises
option_4: to help them breathe underwater
option_1_explanation: You may have focused on the detail that tree frogs eat bugs and assumed the toes help catch them. But the text says, “Each toe has a suction cup… These suction cups help tree frogs stick to anything they want to climb,” even windows, so the correct answer is to help them stick to things they climb. Next time, find the sentence that explains the feature and choose the answer that matches those exact words.
option_2_explanation: You successfully identified a key detail by explaining why tree frogs have suction cups. The text supports this when it says, “These suction cups help tree frogs stick to anything they want to climb.” Remember to look for clue words like “help” or “so” that tell the purpose of a feature when answering similar questions.
option_3_explanation: You may have focused on the detail that tree frogs “can make a lot of noise,” but that sentence isn’t about their toes. The passage says, “Each toe has a suction cup… These suction cups help tree frogs stick to anything they want to climb,” so the toes are for sticking, not making noise. Next time, match the body part named in the question with the sentence that explains its job and look for clue words like “help.”
option_4_explanation: You may have mixed up details about breathing with the frogs’ toes; the text says, “When they are babies, they have gills… This helps them breathe underwater,” but it also says, “Each toe has a suction cup… These suction cups help tree frogs stick to anything they want to climb,” even windows. So suction cups are for sticking to things they climb, not for breathing. Next time, reread the sentence about the body part named in the question and make sure your answer matches what that sentence says.

passage_text:
Tree Frogs
    
    
        Amphibians are special animals that live in two places. They spend part of their lives in water and part on land. When they are babies, they have gills like fish. This helps them breathe underwater. Later, they grow lungs so they can breathe air on land. Tree frogs are one kind of amphibian. They are different because they spend most of their time up in trees.
The American green tree frog lives in the southeastern United States. These frogs are very small. A typical tree frog is only about two inches long. But they can make a lot of noise when many of them get together. If you live in the southern United States near water and trees, you might hear their gentle chirps on summer nights.

---

American tree frogs can be lime green or yellow in color. Their most special feature is their long toes. Each toe has a suction cup at the end. These suction cups help tree frogs stick to anything they want to climb. They can even stick to windows! Tree frogs like to stay up in trees, so you will probably hear them before you see them. They only come down to lay their eggs. They are most likely to come to the ground after heavy rain, when everything is wet.
If you do see a tree frog, don't be scared! They are friendly animals. They are easy to catch too. If you catch one, it might sit on your hand or crawl on your back. You will probably only find them at night because they are nocturnal. This means they sleep during the day and are awake at night. They eat small bugs like crickets and moths.

---

Like other amphibians, American green tree frogs lay their eggs in or near water. Most of them like to put their eggs very close to water, but not right in it. Their favorite spot is on a tree branch that has fallen into a pond. Tree frogs have been around for a very long time. They lived on Earth even before dinosaurs! You can find different types of tree frogs in North America, South America, Europe, and Southeast Asia.
Most tree frogs like a warm, wet climate. If you live where tree frogs are found, you are lucky! In the summer, you can fall asleep listening to the sounds of many tree frogs singing together. It sounds like a beautiful orchestra of nature.

These positive descriptions show the author believes the sounds are pleasant. When identifying beliefs, pay attention to descriptive words that show feelings and opinions.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The author explains that what makes tree frogs special is that 'they spend most of their time up in trees,' not in water. This shows the author appreciates their tree-dwelling nature. You may have confused general amphibian traits with what the author values about tree frogs specifically.

You can find different types of tree frogs in North America, South America, Europe, and Southeast Asia.
Most tree frogs like a warm, wet climate. If you live where tree frogs are found, you are lucky! In the summer, you can fall asleep listening to the sounds of many tree frogs singing together. It sounds like a beautiful orchestra of nature.

        Amphibians are special animals that live in two places. They spend part of their lives in water and part on land. When they are babies, they have gills like fish. ---

passage_text:
The Komodo Dragon
    
    
        You have probably heard stories about dragons that breathe fire and fly around scaring people. A brave knight usually comes to save the day in these fairy tales. But real fire-breathing dragons never existed. However, there is one real dragon that lives today: the Komodo dragon. This dragon does not breathe fire or fly. It is just a very big reptile that can be quite dangerous. These animals have attacked people before, so you need to be very careful around them.
These special dragons get their name from the island of Komodo. This remote island is part of a country called Indonesia. You can also find Komodo dragons on four or five other islands nearby. But they are very rare animals. They like to live in hot, dry places. Each dragon digs a burrow in the ground that is two to three feet deep. Like most reptiles, they spend most of their time sleeping or resting in their burrow.

---

A Komodo dragon can grow as big as a crocodile or even bigger! They can weigh up to 150 pounds and grow over ten feet long from head to tail. The biggest one ever found weighed 370 pounds. That is as heavy as about six third-grade students put together!
Like many reptiles, Komodo dragons cannot hear or see very well. But they have a very strong sense of smell. Here is something amazing: they do not use their nostril to smell things. Instead, they use their tongue! They stick out their tongue to smell food that is several miles away. This works best when the wind blows the smell toward them.

---

Komodo dragons are carnivores, which means they eat meat. Most of the time, they eat dead animals they find. But when they cannot find dead animals, they hunt for fresh food. They have very sharp claws and teeth. When they need to, they can move quite fast. They are the only lizards that can attack and eat animals bigger than themselves. They might hunt goats, deer, and even huge water buffalo!
Young Komodo dragons eat insects, small mammals, and birds. They climb trees to catch their prey. They will eat anything they can catch with their claws, as long as it has meat.

---

You never want a Komodo dragon to bite you or even lick you! Their saliva is full of dangerous germs that can make people very sick. The saliva in their mouth contains bacteria that can be deadly. The safest way to see a Komodo dragon is at a zoo. Only very brave scientists should get close to them in the wild!
question: The author of this passage would most likely agree that
option_1: Komodo dragons should be respected from a distance.
option_2: All dragons are just make-believe creatures.
option_3: Only fairy tale dragons are truly dangerous.
option_4: People should try to pet Komodo dragons at zoos.
option_1_explanation: You successfully identified key details to make a smart conclusion. The text supports this when it says, “These animals have attacked people before, so you need to be very careful around them,” and “The safest way to see a Komodo dragon is at a zoo.” Remember to look for warning words and safety clues in the passage when answering similar questions.
option_2_explanation: You may have focused on the fairy-tale part and thought all dragons are pretend, but the text says, “there is one real dragon that lives today: the Komodo dragon.” It also explains they can attack people and their saliva has deadly germs, so the best answer is that Komodo dragons should be respected from a distance. Next time, read the whole paragraph and watch for clue words like “However” that show a change in the author’s point.
option_3_explanation: You may have focused on the fairy-tale part, but the passage says the real Komodo dragon “can be quite dangerous,” has “attacked people,” and its saliva “can be deadly,” so your choice is not true. This shows we should keep our distance—Komodo dragons should be respected from a distance. Next time, reread the safety lines and look for clue words like dangerous and attacked to be sure your answer matches the text.
option_4_explanation: You may have thought that seeing them at a zoo means it’s safe to pet them, but the text says they have attacked people and their saliva can be deadly, and it says the safest way is to see them at a zoo—see, not touch. That’s why the correct idea is to respect Komodo dragons from a distance. Next time, reread the lines with the clue and make sure your answer matches exactly what the text says.

passage_text:
The Komodo Dragon
    
    
        You have probably heard stories about dragons that breathe fire and fly around scaring people. A brave knight usually comes to save the day in these fairy tales. But real fire-breathing dragons never existed. However, there is one real dragon that lives today: the Komodo dragon. This dragon does not breathe fire or fly. It is just a very big reptile that can be quite dangerous. These animals have attacked people before, so you need to be very careful around them.
These special dragons get their name from the island of Komodo. This remote island is part of a country called Indonesia. You can also find Komodo dragons on four or five other islands nearby. But they are very rare animals. They like to live in hot, dry places. Each dragon digs a burrow in the ground that is two to three feet deep. Like most reptiles, they spend most of their time sleeping or resting in their burrow.

---

A Komodo dragon can grow as big as a crocodile or even bigger! They can weigh up to 150 pounds and grow over ten feet long from head to tail. The biggest one ever found weighed 370 pounds. That is as heavy as about six third-grade students put together!
Like many reptiles, Komodo dragons cannot hear or see very well. But they have a very strong sense of smell. Here is something amazing: they do not use their nostril to smell things. Instead, they use their tongue! They stick out their tongue to smell food that is several miles away. This works best when the wind blows the smell toward them.

---

Komodo dragons are carnivores, which means they eat meat. Most of the time, they eat dead animals they find. But when they cannot find dead animals, they hunt for fresh food. They have very sharp claws and teeth. When they need to, they can move quite fast. They are the only lizards that can attack and eat animals bigger than themselves. They might hunt goats, deer, and even huge water buffalo!
Young Komodo dragons eat insects, small mammals, and birds. They climb trees to catch their prey. They will eat anything they can catch with their claws, as long as it has meat.

---

You never want a Komodo dragon to bite you or even lick you! Their saliva is full of dangerous germs that can make people very sick. The saliva in their mouth contains bacteria that can be deadly. The safest way to see a Komodo dragon is at a zoo. Only very brave scientists should get close to them in the wild!
question: Which idea would the author most likely support about protecting Komodo dragons?
option_1: We should capture all Komodo dragons and keep them in cages.
option_2: We should destroy their burrows to keep people safe.
option_3: We should preserve their remote island habitats.
option_4: We should move them to colder climates away from people.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. While the author mentions zoos as safe places to view them, the passage describes their natural behavior and habitat with interest and respect. The author would not support removing all of them from the wild.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. The passage describes their burrows as natural homes where they rest, and explains they live on remote islands. The author would not support destroying their natural habitat just to keep people away from these rare animals.
option_3_explanation: Correct! The author describes Komodo dragons as 'very rare animals' living on 'remote' islands, and explains their natural behaviors with respect. The emphasis on their rarity and natural habitat suggests the author would support preserving where they live.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The passage explains 'They like to live in hot, dry places' and describes their Indonesian island habitat. Moving them to colder climates would go against their natural needs that the author carefully describes.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 2 about habitat and rarity - differs from reference by asking about conservation rather than viewing safety.
homogeneity_check: all choices are statements about managing Komodo dragon populations
specificity_check: all choices describe specific actions regarding Komodo dragons
length_check: A=11 words, B=9 words, C=7 words, D=10 words - balanced within 15%
semantic_distance_check: choices cover capture, destroy habitat, preserve habitat, relocate - distinct management approaches
single_correct_check: only C aligns with author's emphasis on rarity and natural habitat description
diversity_check: targets paragraph 2 about habitat and rarity - completely different from reference about viewing distance and other variants about scientists, danger comparison, or interaction

option_1: They are being very responsible and careful.

option_3: They are taking a foolish and unsafe risk.

option_4_explanation: Incorrect. While the author mentions scientists studying Komodo dragons, the passage emphasizes that 'Only very brave scientists should get close to them.' Regular people hand-feeding them would not be helping science - they would be ignoring safety warnings.

passage_text:
The Komodo Dragon
    
    
        You have probably heard stories about dragons that breathe fire and fly around scaring people. A brave knight usually comes to save the day in these fairy tales. But real fire-breathing dragons never existed. However, there is one real dragon that lives today: the Komodo dragon. This dragon does not breathe fire or fly. It is just a very big reptile that can be quite dangerous. These animals have attacked people before, so you need to be very careful around them.
These special dragons get their name from the island of Komodo. This remote island is part of a country called Indonesia. You can also find Komodo dragons on four or five other islands nearby. But they are very rare animals. They like to live in hot, dry places. Each dragon digs a burrow in the ground that is two to three feet deep. Like most reptiles, they spend most of their time sleeping or resting in their burrow.

---

A Komodo dragon can grow as big as a crocodile or even bigger! They can weigh up to 150 pounds and grow over ten feet long from head to tail. The biggest one ever found weighed 370 pounds. That is as heavy as about six third-grade students put together!
Like many reptiles, Komodo dragons cannot hear or see very well. But they have a very strong sense of smell. Here is something amazing: they do not use their nostril to smell things. Instead, they use their tongue! They stick out their tongue to smell food that is several miles away. This works best when the wind blows the smell toward them.

---

Komodo dragons are carnivores, which means they eat meat. Most of the time, they eat dead animals they find. But when they cannot find dead animals, they hunt for fresh food. They have very sharp claws and teeth. When they need to, they can move quite fast. They are the only lizards that can attack and eat animals bigger than themselves. They might hunt goats, deer, and even huge water buffalo!
Young Komodo dragons eat insects, small mammals, and birds. They climb trees to catch their prey. They will eat anything they can catch with their claws, as long as it has meat.

---

You never want a Komodo dragon to bite you or even lick you! Their saliva is full of dangerous germs that can make people very sick. The saliva in their mouth contains bacteria that can be deadly. The safest way to see a Komodo dragon is at a zoo. Only very brave scientists should get close to them in the wild!
question: Why does the author explain that Komodo dragons use their tongue instead of their nostrils to smell?
option_1: To prove that Komodo dragons are the smartest reptiles.
option_2: To show an unusual way these animals sense their environment.
option_3: To explain why Komodo dragons cannot breathe properly.
option_4: To describe how Komodo dragons defend themselves from enemies.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. The passage does not compare Komodo dragons' intelligence to other reptiles. The author simply describes their unique smelling ability, not their smartness compared to other animals.
option_2_explanation: Correct! The author states 'Here is something amazing' before explaining how they use their tongue to smell. This shows the author wants to highlight an unusual and interesting sensory ability that makes Komodo dragons different from most animals.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The passage does not suggest Komodo dragons have breathing problems. The author explains they use their tongue for smelling food, which is separate from breathing through nostrils.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The passage describes the tongue being used to 'smell food that is several miles away,' which is about finding prey for hunting, not defending against enemies. Defense is not mentioned in this section.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 2 about author's purpose for tongue explanation - differs from reference which asks what function the tongue serves. This asks why the author included this detail.
homogeneity_check: all choices are statements about the author's purpose for including information
specificity_check: all choices explain potential reasons for including the tongue detail
length_check: A=10 words, B=10 words, C=9 words, D=9 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: choices cover intelligence proof, unusual sensing, breathing problems, defense - distinct purposes
single_correct_check: only B aligns with author's 'Here is something amazing' framing of the detail
diversity_check: targets paragraph 2 about author's purpose - completely different from reference about tongue function and other variants

question: Based on the passage, what relationship exists between a Komodo dragon's size and its hunting ability?
option_1: Their large size prevents them from catching any prey at all.
option_2: Their large size allows them to attack animals bigger than themselves.
option_3: Their large size forces them to only eat tiny insects.
option_4: Their large size makes them too slow to hunt successfully.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. The passage describes Komodo dragons as successful hunters that eat goats, deer, and water buffalo. Their size clearly does not prevent them from catching prey - it helps them catch large animals.
option_2_explanation: Correct! The passage states 'They are the only lizards that can attack and eat animals bigger than themselves. They might hunt goats, deer, and even huge water buffalo!' This shows their large size gives them the ability to hunt very large prey.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. While young Komodo dragons eat insects, adult dragons that grow very large eat much bigger animals. The passage says they hunt 'goats, deer, and even huge water buffalo,' not tiny insects.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Although the passage says 'Like many reptiles, Komodo dragons cannot hear or see very well,' it also states 'When they need to, they can move quite fast' for hunting. Their size does not make them too slow to hunt.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 3 about size-hunting relationship - differs from reference by requiring analysis of cause-effect relationship between two concepts rather than identifying a single function.

specificity_check: all choices describe specific effects of size on hunting capability

option_1: Young dragons swim underwater while adults hunt on land.

Like many reptiles, Komodo dragons cannot hear or see very well. But they have a very strong sense of smell. Here is something amazing: they do not use their nostril to smell things. Instead, they use their tongue! They stick out their tongue to smell food that is several miles away. This works best when the wind blows the smell toward them.

---

Komodo dragons are carnivores, which means they eat meat. Most of the time, they eat dead animals they find. But when they cannot find dead animals, they hunt for fresh food. They have very sharp claws and teeth. When they need to, they can move quite fast. They are the only lizards that can attack and eat animals bigger than themselves. They might hunt goats, deer, and even huge water buffalo!
Young Komodo dragons eat insects, small mammals, and birds. They climb trees to catch their prey. They will eat anything they can catch with their claws, as long as it has meat.

---

You never want a Komodo dragon to bite you or even lick you! Their saliva is full of dangerous germs that can make people very sick. The saliva in their mouth contains bacteria that can be deadly. The safest way to see a Komodo dragon is at a zoo. Only very brave scientists should get close to them in the wild!
question: According to the last paragraph, what does the author explain about the connection between Komodo dragon saliva and human safety?
option_1: Their saliva contains helpful medicine for sick people.
option_2: Their saliva has dangerous germs that cause serious illness.
option_3: Their saliva keeps their teeth clean and healthy.
option_4: Their saliva helps them digest large animals they eat.

option_2_explanation: Correct! The passage states 'Their saliva is full of dangerous germs that can make people very sick' and 'The saliva in their mouth contains bacteria that can be deadly.' This clearly explains the dangerous connection between their saliva and human safety.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The passage does not discuss dental health or teeth cleaning. The saliva discussion focuses entirely on the danger it poses to people through 'dangerous germs' and 'deadly' bacteria, not on benefits to the dragon.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. While the passage describes what Komodo dragons eat, it does not explain that saliva helps with digestion. The saliva discussion is specifically about the danger to humans from 'dangerous germs' and bacteria.

passage_text:
The Komodo Dragon
    
    
        You have probably heard stories about dragons that breathe fire and fly around scaring people. A brave knight usually comes to save the day in these fairy tales. But real fire-breathing dragons never existed. However, there is one real dragon that lives today: the Komodo dragon. This dragon does not breathe fire or fly. It is just a very big reptile that can be quite dangerous. These animals have attacked people before, so you need to be very careful around them.
These special dragons get their name from the island of Komodo. This remote island is part of a country called Indonesia. You can also find Komodo dragons on four or five other islands nearby. But they are very rare animals. They like to live in hot, dry places. Each dragon digs a burrow in the ground that is two to three feet deep. Like most reptiles, they spend most of their time sleeping or resting in their burrow.

---

A Komodo dragon can grow as big as a crocodile or even bigger! They can weigh up to 150 pounds and grow over ten feet long from head to tail. The biggest one ever found weighed 370 pounds. That is as heavy as about six third-grade students put together!
Like many reptiles, Komodo dragons cannot hear or see very well. But they have a very strong sense of smell. Here is something amazing: they do not use their nostril to smell things. Instead, they use their tongue! They stick out their tongue to smell food that is several miles away. This works best when the wind blows the smell toward them.

---

Komodo dragons are carnivores, which means they eat meat. Most of the time, they eat dead animals they find. But when they cannot find dead animals, they hunt for fresh food. They have very sharp claws and teeth. When they need to, they can move quite fast. They are the only lizards that can attack and eat animals bigger than themselves. They might hunt goats, deer, and even huge water buffalo!
Young Komodo dragons eat insects, small mammals, and birds. They climb trees to catch their prey. They will eat anything they can catch with their claws, as long as it has meat.

---

You never want a Komodo dragon to bite you or even lick you! Their saliva is full of dangerous germs that can make people very sick. The saliva in their mouth contains bacteria that can be deadly. The safest way to see a Komodo dragon is at a zoo. Only very brave scientists should get close to them in the wild!

option_2: explain where Komodo dragons live on remote islands.
option_3: make 370 pounds easier for young readers to picture.
option_4: describe the sharp claws and teeth these animals have.

option_2_explanation: Incorrect. The comparison to six third-graders is about weight (370 pounds), not location. Information about remote islands in Indonesia appears in a different part of the passage and is unrelated to this weight comparison.
option_3_explanation: Correct! The passage states 'The biggest one ever found weighed 370 pounds. That is as heavy as about six third-grade students put together!' This comparison helps young readers understand the abstract number 370 pounds by relating it to something familiar - the weight of students their age.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The comparison about weight ('370 pounds...as heavy as about six third-grade students') is unrelated to their claws and teeth. The author discusses sharp claws and teeth in paragraph 3 when describing hunting, not when explaining weight.

passage_text:
Beavers
    
    
        Beavers are special mammals that do important work in nature. These animals have two main features that help them survive. First, they have long, sharp teeth that they use to gnaw down trees. To gnaw means to bite and chew on something hard. Second, they have flat, wide tails that help them swim fast in the water. Their tails also work like alarm bells. When a beaver sees danger, it slaps its tail hard on the water to warn other beavers.
Beavers live near ponds and lakes in North America, Europe, and Asia. Today, it is hard to find beavers in the wild. Long ago, people hunted so many beavers that they almost disappeared forever. This is called extinction. People wanted beaver pelts, which are the furry skins of animals. They used these pelts to make warm coats and hats. Even today, some people still hunt beavers or think they cause problems.

---

Beavers are the second biggest rodent in the world. A rodent is a type of animal with big front teeth, like mice, rats, and hamsters. People often say "busy as a beaver" because these animals work all the time. They spend most of their day in the water building things. Beavers are famous for making dams across rivers and streams. They build these dams to make the water deeper, which keeps them safe from bears and other animals that might hurt them.
When beavers sense danger, they can dive underwater and hold their breath for up to 15 minutes! They move slowly on land, but they swim very well. After building a dam, beavers make homes called lodges. These lodges are big piles of sticks and mud. Beavers use their strong teeth to gnaw down trees of all sizes. Then they eat the bark from the trees and use the leftover wood to build their dams and lodges.

---

One beaver family can change the land around them in big ways. Their dams make the water in rivers rise higher. This floods the land nearby and creates a swamp called a wetland. A wetland is a special place where land and water mix together. Many birds, fish, and insects need wetlands to live. However, people who live nearby might not like the flooding that beavers cause.
Beavers don't stay in one place very long. When they eat all the good tree bark in an area, they move down the river to start over. But the wetland they made often stays there long after they leave. Beavers are also very territorial. This means they don't want other beavers living in their space. They want to keep all the tasty tree bark for themselves! They will fight other beavers who try to move into their area. Beavers are truly amazing animals to watch and learn about.
question: According to the passage about beavers, what do beavers need to build their dams and lodges?
option_1: pelts from other animals
option_2: sharp teeth and flat tails
option_3: deep water from ponds and lakes
option_4: trees they gnaw down with their teeth
option_1_explanation: You may have mixed up what people wanted from beavers with what beavers use to build; the text says “People wanted beaver pelts…to make warm coats and hats,” but also says, “Beavers use their strong teeth to gnaw down trees… and use the leftover wood to build their dams and lodges.” So the correct answer is trees they gnaw down with their teeth. Strategy: Reread the question and underline clue words like build and use, then find the sentence in the passage that matches those words.
option_2_explanation: It looks like you focused on the beaver’s body parts instead of what they build with. The text says, “Beavers use their strong teeth to gnaw down trees… then use the leftover wood to build their dams and lodges,” so the material is trees (wood), not sharp teeth and flat tails. The correct answer is trees they gnaw down with their teeth. Next time, reread the question and look for clue words like “build” to find the material, not the tool.
option_3_explanation: You may have mixed up where beavers live with what they build with. The passage says, “Beavers use their strong teeth to gnaw down trees… and use the leftover wood to build their dams and lodges,” so they don’t use deep water to build. The correct answer is trees they gnaw down with their teeth. Next time, reread for key words like “use” and “build” to make sure you choose the material, not the habitat.
option_4_explanation: Great job—you identified key details by noticing what beavers use to build. The text says, “Beavers use their strong teeth to gnaw down trees… and use the leftover wood to build their dams and lodges,” which matches your answer. When you get questions like this, look closely for sentences that explain what the animal uses or does.

Beavers are also very territorial. This means they don't want other beavers living in their space. They want to keep all the tasty tree bark for themselves! They will fight other beavers who try to move into their area. Beavers are truly amazing animals to watch and learn about.
question: Why do beavers build dams across rivers and streams?
option_1: to make the water deeper for safety
option_2: to create places to store wood
option_3: to stop other animals from drinking
option_4: to catch fish for food

The text supports this: “They build these dams to make the water deeper, which keeps them safe from bears and other animals.” When you see a “why” question, look for the sentence that gives the reason, often with words like “because” or “which keeps.”
option_2_explanation: You may have focused on the detail that beavers use leftover wood to build, but the text says, “They build these dams to make the water deeper, which keeps them safe from bears and other animals,” showing the reason is safety, not storing wood. So the correct answer is to make the water deeper for safety. Next time, when a question asks why, reread and look for purpose words like “to make” or “to keep” that tell the main reason.

passage_text:
Beavers
    
    
        Beavers are special mammals that do important work in nature. These animals have two main features that help them survive. First, they have long, sharp teeth that they use to gnaw down trees. To gnaw means to bite and chew on something hard. Second, they have flat, wide tails that help them swim fast in the water. Their tails also work like alarm bells. When a beaver sees danger, it slaps its tail hard on the water to warn other beavers.
Beavers live near ponds and lakes in North America, Europe, and Asia. Today, it is hard to find beavers in the wild. Long ago, people hunted so many beavers that they almost disappeared forever. This is called extinction. People wanted beaver pelts, which are the furry skins of animals. They used these pelts to make warm coats and hats. Even today, some people still hunt beavers or think they cause problems.

---

Beavers are the second biggest rodent in the world. A rodent is a type of animal with big front teeth, like mice, rats, and hamsters. People often say "busy as a beaver" because these animals work all the time. They spend most of their day in the water building things. Beavers are famous for making dams across rivers and streams. They build these dams to make the water deeper, which keeps them safe from bears and other animals that might hurt them.
When beavers sense danger, they can dive underwater and hold their breath for up to 15 minutes! They move slowly on land, but they swim very well. After building a dam, beavers make homes called lodges. These lodges are big piles of sticks and mud. Beavers use their strong teeth to gnaw down trees of all sizes. Then they eat the bark from the trees and use the leftover wood to build their dams and lodges.

---

One beaver family can change the land around them in big ways. Their dams make the water in rivers rise higher. This floods the land nearby and creates a swamp called a wetland. A wetland is a special place where land and water mix together. Many birds, fish, and insects need wetlands to live. However, people who live nearby might not like the flooding that beavers cause.
Beavers don't stay in one place very long. When they eat all the good tree bark in an area, they move down the river to start over. But the wetland they made often stays there long after they leave. Beavers are also very territorial. This means they don't want other beavers living in their space. They want to keep all the tasty tree bark for themselves! They will fight other beavers who try to move into their area. Beavers are truly amazing animals to watch and learn about.
question: Why did beavers almost disappear forever long ago?
option_1: because they moved to new rivers and couldn't find food
option_2: because people hunted them for their warm, furry pelts
option_3: because other animals attacked them in their lodges
option_4: because wetlands dried up and destroyed their homes
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. While beavers do move when food runs out, this is normal behavior, not the reason they almost went extinct. The passage describes moving as typical beaver behavior, not a threat to their survival.
option_2_explanation: Correct! The passage clearly states 'Long ago, people hunted so many beavers that they almost disappeared forever' and 'People wanted beaver pelts, which are the furry skins of animals.' When answering 'why' questions, look for explicit cause-and-effect statements in the text.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The passage mentions beavers build dams for safety from predators like bears, but it doesn't say predator attacks caused near-extinction. The text identifies hunting by people, not animal attacks, as the main threat.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Beavers CREATE wetlands; they don't depend on naturally existing ones. The passage explains that beaver dams cause flooding that makes wetlands, so drying wetlands wouldn't be the cause of their disappearance.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 1 about historical hunting causing near-extinction - differs from reference which asks about what beavers need to build
homogeneity_check: all choices are potential reasons for population decline
specificity_check: all describe environmental or behavioral threats with similar detail

semantic_distance_check: migration (A) vs hunting (B) vs predation (C) vs habitat loss (D) - distinct threat categories
single_correct_check: only B matches the explicit explanation for near-extinction in the text
diversity_check: targets paragraph 1 hunting/extinction threat - completely different from reference's building focus

question: Based on the passage, what do beavers do when they sense danger?
option_1: They dive underwater and can stay there for 15 minutes.

option_3: They hide inside their lodges made of sticks and mud.

option_1_explanation: Correct! The passage states 'When beavers sense danger, they can dive underwater and hold their breath for up to 15 minutes!' This is a direct answer to what beavers do when threatened. Look for action words that follow phrases like 'when' to find cause-and-effect relationships.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. While beavers do have sharp teeth, the passage says they use these for gnawing trees, not fighting predators. The text describes their teeth as tools for cutting wood and eating bark.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The passage doesn't say beavers hide in their lodges when sensing danger. Lodges provide general protection, but the specific response to immediate danger is diving underwater.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The passage mentions beavers 'move slowly on land,' but this is a general description of their movement, not a response to danger. In fact, being slow on land makes them MORE vulnerable, which is why they dive underwater.

question: What is the most likely reason the author wrote this passage?
option_1: to give readers information about different types of rodents
option_2: to tell readers a story about animals that live in water
option_3: to teach readers about an important animal in nature
option_4: to help readers understand how to build dams
option_1_explanation: You may have focused on a supporting detail (the word “rodent”) and thought the author was listing different rodents, but the title is “Beavers” and each paragraph explains what beavers do—gnaw trees, build dams, and create wetlands. The line “Beavers are the second biggest rodent” only labels what kind of animal they are; it doesn’t change the topic, so the author’s purpose is to teach readers about an important animal in nature. Next time, match your answer to the title and the ideas repeated through the whole passage, not just one word.
option_2_explanation: You may have thought it was a story about water animals, but look at the facts and definitions in the text, like “gnaw means to bite and chew,” “Beavers are special mammals,” and details about building dams and lodges, which show it isn’t a story. These facts explain how beavers live and why they matter (they make wetlands that many animals need), so the purpose is to teach readers about an important animal in nature. Next time, ask yourself: Is this telling a story with events, or giving facts and vocabulary to teach me something?
option_3_explanation: You successfully identified the author’s purpose by noticing the passage gives facts and definitions about beavers to inform readers. The text supports this when it says, “Beavers are special mammals that do important work in nature,” and explains “two main features that help them survive,” plus how they build dams. Remember to look for facts, definitions, and examples to figure out when a text is meant to teach.
option_4_explanation: You may have focused on the detail that beavers build dams, but the passage doesn’t give steps or directions for building dams. Instead, it explains many facts about beavers—their teeth and tails, where they live, why they build dams, and how they create wetlands—showing the purpose is to teach about an important animal in nature. Next time, ask yourself, “What is the whole passage mostly about?” and pick the answer that fits the big idea, not just one detail.

passage_text:
Beavers
    
    
        Beavers are special mammals that do important work in nature. These animals have two main features that help them survive. First, they have long, sharp teeth that they use to gnaw down trees. To gnaw means to bite and chew on something hard. Second, they have flat, wide tails that help them swim fast in the water. Their tails also work like alarm bells. When a beaver sees danger, it slaps its tail hard on the water to warn other beavers.
Beavers live near ponds and lakes in North America, Europe, and Asia. Today, it is hard to find beavers in the wild. Long ago, people hunted so many beavers that they almost disappeared forever. This is called extinction. People wanted beaver pelts, which are the furry skins of animals. They used these pelts to make warm coats and hats. Even today, some people still hunt beavers or think they cause problems.

---

Beavers are the second biggest rodent in the world. A rodent is a type of animal with big front teeth, like mice, rats, and hamsters. People often say "busy as a beaver" because these animals work all the time. They spend most of their day in the water building things. Beavers are famous for making dams across rivers and streams. They build these dams to make the water deeper, which keeps them safe from bears and other animals that might hurt them.
When beavers sense danger, they can dive underwater and hold their breath for up to 15 minutes! They move slowly on land, but they swim very well. After building a dam, beavers make homes called lodges. These lodges are big piles of sticks and mud. Beavers use their strong teeth to gnaw down trees of all sizes. Then they eat the bark from the trees and use the leftover wood to build their dams and lodges.

---

One beaver family can change the land around them in big ways. Their dams make the water in rivers rise higher. This floods the land nearby and creates a swamp called a wetland. A wetland is a special place where land and water mix together. Many birds, fish, and insects need wetlands to live. However, people who live nearby might not like the flooding that beavers cause.
Beavers don't stay in one place very long. When they eat all the good tree bark in an area, they move down the river to start over. But the wetland they made often stays there long after they leave. Beavers are also very territorial. This means they don't want other beavers living in their space. They want to keep all the tasty tree bark for themselves! They will fight other beavers who try to move into their area. Beavers are truly amazing animals to watch and learn about.
question: Based on the passage, what is the most likely reason the author included information about beaver hunting and extinction?
option_1: to explain why beavers are now protected by laws in many places
option_2: to show that beavers have faced challenges from humans in the past
option_3: to teach readers how to recognize valuable animal pelts and furs
option_4: to convince readers that hunting all wild animals should be illegal
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. The passage mentions hunting almost caused extinction but doesn't discuss current protection laws. While this might be true in real life, the text doesn't provide this information, so you cannot select an answer based on outside knowledge.
option_2_explanation: Correct! The author includes the hunting information to show human impact on beavers: 'Long ago, people hunted so many beavers that they almost disappeared forever.' This demonstrates historical challenges. When analyzing author's purpose, consider what message each section conveys about the broader topic.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The passage mentions pelts were valuable but doesn't teach readers how to identify them. The author's purpose is informing about beavers, not instructing about fur identification.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The passage doesn't argue that all hunting should be illegal. It presents historical facts about beaver hunting without making broad statements about hunting policy. Don't confuse stating facts with advocating positions.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 1 about why author included hunting history - differs from reference by asking about specific section purpose rather than overall purpose
homogeneity_check: all choices are potential author motivations for including information
specificity_check: all describe possible reasons with similar explanation depth
length_check: A=12 words, B=12 words, C=12 words, D=11 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: legal protection (A) vs historical challenges (B) vs educational instruction (C) vs advocacy (D) - distinct purposes
single_correct_check: only B aligns with the informational purpose shown in the text
diversity_check: targets paragraph 1 analyzing specific section purpose (hunting info) - different from reference's overall purpose and variant 1's supporting detail

This description helps readers visualize beaver behavior. Authors often use familiar phrases to connect new information to what readers already know.

option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The author is informing readers about beavers, not giving advice about work habits. Informational texts present facts, not personal recommendations. The phrase describes beavers, not what people should do.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The passage uses the saying to describe beavers but doesn't explain the phrase's historical origins or etymology. The author assumes readers know the phrase and uses it to emphasize beaver activity levels.

This directly tells readers where beavers build homes - after dams, as lodges made of specific materials. Look for sentences that directly answer location questions.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. This explains why beavers build dams (for safety), not where their homes are located. Dams and lodges (homes) are different structures, even though they're related.
